audio_caption: The audio clip features a single male speaker, explaining how waves transfer energy, mentioning soundwaves transferring energy from a speaker to an ear, and that waves generally involve some kind of oscillation. He lists wave experiments, such as water waves, light waves, and waves in ropes.

The clip starts with a male speaker beginning an educational explanation, "Now we need to learn a few terms," in a clear, instructional tone. He defines terms related to waves, describing the "wavefront" and using a photograph as a visual reference. The speaker notes a line where the wave does the same thing and is all at a peak. The clip concludes with a brief musical note.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing wave speed, explaining how it's measured and giving an example using a jet going faster than the speed of sound, creating a sonic boom. A sound of something flushing follows.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker defining "frequency" as "the number of wave cycles per second," measured in hertz. He continues to explain that humans typically hear from "20 to 20,000 hertz," speaking in an informative tone.

The clip features a single male speaker explaining the concept of wavelength, defining it as "the distance it takes for the wave to repeat itself" and noting that it is measured in meters. His tone is instructional and clear as he references a diagram with examples. He notes that the symbol "lambda" is the one used for wavelength, before the clip abruptly ends.
The audio clip features one male speaker comparing two waves, noting that "the red wave here" has "a much smaller wavelength" than the blue wave. The speaker then mentions "amplitude."

The audio clip begins with a male speaker defining the amplitude of a wave as "the distance from the peak... to the rest position" and noting that it's measured in meters. He speaks in an educational tone, explaining what happens when there is no wave, and describing the amplitude from the rest position to the peak or trough. He notes these distances are the same. The clip concludes with a deep musical note.

The audio features a single male speaker, presenting information on the wave equation, emphasizing "wave speed," "frequency," and "wavelength" with a clear, educational tone. He explains the relationships between these elements, offering a formula and a triangle visualization. His tone is informative throughout.

The clip begins with a single male speaker, who in a relatively calm and educational tone defines reflection as a property of waves, explaining how it occurs when a wave meets a boundary, and uses the example of a man shouting on an island and the sound wave echoing off a cliff to illustrate the concept. After the detailed explanation, the same male speaker says "refraction."

The clip features a male speaker describing how the speed of waves can change when traveling between different materials, leading to refraction. He uses light entering a glass or plastic block as an example, explaining how the wave slows down and bends. Then he switches to water waves moving from deeper to shallower water, noting the change in wave speed and the corresponding bending.

A male speaker explains diffraction, mentioning how waves spread when encountering a slit. He points out that the smaller the gap, the bigger the spreading, and explains the relationship between frequency, wavelength, and spreading, with a calm and informative tone.

The clip begins with one male speaker discussing diffraction, explaining that "diffraction explains why you can hear someone." He provides an example, imagining a person standing near a doorway and explaining that "as the wave enters through, that wave will spread out and diffract around." The speaker uses a clear and informative tone.
